required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of Interference Between Bioelectrical Impedance Analysis and Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillators
clinical_study.official_title: Use of Bioelectrical Impedance Analysis in the Nutritional Assessment of Patients With CHF Equipped With Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillators

brief_summary.textblock: Evaluation of electromagnetic interference between Bioelectrical Impedance Analysis (BIA) and implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICDs).

detailed_description.textblock:
Electrograms of ICDs will be analyzed during wireless telemetry and during body composition measurement using BIA. ICD therapy will have been temporarily inactivated before the measurement to avoid inappropriate shocks, and the sensitivity level of the ICD will be set to maximum. Body composition will be measured at three frequencies (5 khz, 50 khz and 100 khz).
Interference will be assessed by the presence of visible artefacts on the real-time electrogram, with ICD marker annotations showing atrial and/or ventricular sensed episodes. The outcome measure will be the number and proportion of patients who have electromagnetic interferences of the ICD when BIA is done.
The procedure will take approximately 5-10minutes, with reprogramming of the device at the end of the test. No further follow-up in the context of the study will be performed.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of patients who have electromagnetic interference of the ICD when exposed to BIA.

intervention.intervention_name: Exposure to BIA interference with the ICD
intervention.description: Exposure to BIA interference with the ICD

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Implantation with a wireless-enabled ICD
Exclusion Criteria:
- Age <18yrs
- Inability to sign an informed consent
- Pacemaker dependancy

reference.citation: Buch E, Bradfield J, Larson T, Horwich T. Effect of bioimpedance body composition analysis on function of implanted cardiac devices. Pacing Clin Electrophysiol. 2012 Jun;35(6):681-4. doi: 10.1111/j.1540-8159.2012.03377.x. Epub 2012 Mar 27.
